messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 46 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: A SAT attack on higher dimensional ErdÅ‘sâ€“Szekeres numbers An extended abstract of this article appeared at EuroComb 2021 [Sch21]. The author was supported by the DFG Grant SCHE 2214/1-1 â€œApproaching Problems from Combinatorics and Geometry using Computer Assistanceâ€. We thank Helena Bergold for many valuable comments and Ralf Hoffmann, Sven Grottke, and Norbert Paschedag for the technical support.

Paper Abstract: Abstract A famous result by ErdÅ‘s and Szekeres (1935) asserts that, for all k,dâˆˆâ„•ğ‘˜ğ‘‘â„•k,d\in\mathbb{N}, there is a smallest integer n=g(d)â€‹(k)ğ‘›superscriptğ‘”ğ‘‘ğ‘˜n=g^{(d)}(k) such that every set of at least nğ‘›n points in â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d} in general position contains a kğ‘˜k-gon, that is, a subset of kğ‘˜k points which is in convex position. In this article, we present a SAT model based on acyclic chirotopes (oriented matroids) to investigate ErdÅ‘sâ€“Szekeres numbers in small dimensions. To solve the SAT instances we use modern SAT solvers and all our unsatisfiability results are verified using DRAT certificates. We show g(3)â€‹(7)=13superscriptğ‘”3713g^{(3)}(7)=13, g(4)â€‹(8)â‰¤13superscriptğ‘”4813g^{(4)}(8)\leq 13, and g(5)â€‹(9)â‰¤13superscriptğ‘”5913g^{(5)}(9)\leq 13, which are the first improvements for decades. For the setting of kğ‘˜k-holes (i.e., kğ‘˜k-gons with no other points in the convex hull), where h(d)â€‹(k)superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘˜h^{(d)}(k) denotes the minimum number nğ‘›n such that every set of at least nğ‘›n points in â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d} in general position contains a kğ‘˜k-hole, we show h(3)â€‹(7)â‰¤14superscriptâ„3714h^{(3)}(7)\leq 14, h(4)â€‹(8)â‰¤13superscriptâ„4813h^{(4)}(8)\leq 13, and h(5)â€‹(9)â‰¤13superscriptâ„5913h^{(5)}(9)\leq 13. Moreover, all obtained bounds are sharp in the setting of acyclic chirotopes and we conjecture them to be sharp also in the original setting of point sets. As a byproduct, we verify previously known bounds. In particular, we present the first computer-assisted proof of the upper bound h(2)â€‹(6)â‰¤g(2)â€‹(9)â‰¤1717superscriptâ„26superscriptğ‘”291717h^{(2)}(6)\leq g^{(2)}(9)\leq 1717 by Gerken (2008).

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 46 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 46"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Enumerating order types for small point sets with applications",
        "Webpage: Enumerating order types for small point sets with applications",
        "Abstract order type extension and new results on the rectilinear crossing number",
        "On convex holes in dğ‘‘d-dimensional point sets",
        "On empty convex polytopes",
        "CaDiCaL at the SAT Race 2019",
        "Oriented Matroids, volume 46 of Encyclopedia of Mathematics and its Applications",
        "On convex polygons determined by a finite planar set",

        "Some more problems on elementary geometry",
        "Representing graphs and hypergraphs by touching polygons in 3d",

        "Generation of oriented matroidsâ€“a graph theoretical approach",

        "Sweeps, arrangements and signotopes",
        "Empty Convex Hexagons in Planar Point Sets",
        "Konvexe FÃ¼nfecke in ebenen Punktmengen",
        "Two extensions of the ErdÅ‘sâ€“Szekeres problem",
        "Sets with no empty convex 777-gons",
        "Ramsey-remainder for convex sets and the ErdÅ‘sâ€“Szekeres theorem",
        "A combinatorial problem on convex nğ‘›n-gons",
        "Axioms and Hulls, volume 606 of LNCS",
        "On the ErdÅ‘sâ€“Szekeres problem",
        "On ErdÅ‘sâ€“Szekeres problem for empty hexagons in the plane",
        "Order Types of Point Sets in the Plane",
        "Point configurations in dğ‘‘d-space without large subsets in convex position",
        "Fast formal proof of the ErdÅ‘sâ€“Szekeres conjecture for convex polygons with at most 6 points",
        "Lectures on Discrete Geometry",
        "The ErdÅ‘sâ€“Szekeres problem on points in convex position â€“ a survey",
        "The Empty Hexagon Theorem",
        "Finding Sets of Points without Empty Convex 6-Gons",
        "Webpage: A SAT attack on higher dimensional ErdÅ‘sâ€“Szekeres numbers",
        "Two disjoint 5-holes in point sets",
        "A SAT attack on higher dimensional ErdÅ‘sâ€“Szekeres numbers",
        "Computer solution to the 17-point ErdÅ‘sâ€“Szekeres problem",
        "On the ErdÅ‘sâ€“Szekeres convex polygon problem",
        "The ErdÅ‘sâ€“Szekeres theorem: Upper bounds and related results",
        "Convex independent sets and 7-holes in restricted planar point sets",
        "Sets in â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\\mathbb{R}^{d} with no large empty convex subsets",
        "On Empty Hexagons",
        "DRAT-trim: Efficient checking and trimming using expressive clausal proofs"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 46 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in A SAT attack on higher dimensional ErdÅ‘sâ€“Szekeres numbers An extended abstract of this article appeared at EuroComb 2021 [Sch21]. The author was supported by the DFG Grant SCHE 2214/1-1 â€œApproaching Problems from Combinatorics and Geometry using Computer Assistanceâ€. We thank Helena Bergold for many valuable comments and Ralf Hoffmann, Sven Grottke, and Norbert Paschedag for the technical support., providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
